captions.text:
I used to be afraid at night. Afraid of the
dark. Afraid that just beyond the point my

eyesight allowed me to see that there was
something lurking. Afraid that the darkness

itself would somehow surround me and swallow
me up, as if darkness were anything more than
simply the absence of light.

I used to be afraid of tomorrow. Afraid that
who I was would continually dictate who I

am and that who I would be might be someone
who I didn't like very much at all, as if
there was no such thing as being made new.

I used to be afraid of opinions. Afraid that
though words would not break my bones, they

certainly would shatter my dreams, as if I
started doing this for the approval of many
rather than the glory of One.

I used to be afraid of failure. Afraid of
losing. Afraid of falling. Afraid of being

wrong, creating busts, and looking absolutely
stupid because who am I to think that I could

ever actually make a difference? As if those
setbacks were anything more than stepping
stones on the path to success.
I used to be afraid. Used to.

But then I did a little research. And by that,
I mean I re-searched, and I re-searched, and

I re-searched, over and over again, and through
all of my re-searching, I kept coming up with
the same exact question:
What room does fear have?

What room does fear have when I cling to trust?
What room does fear have when I lean on hope?

What room does fear have when I search for
something more, when I discover what's good,

and when I stand in awe? When I run with perseverance,
when I walk by faith, and when I rest in comfort.

What room does fear have when I sing with
praise, when I take hold of inspiration, explore

the possibilities, and step into freedom?
What room does fear have when I discover strength,

embrace courage, remember peace, declare truth,
choose joy, experience life, and conquer death?

What room does fear have when I find perfection
in the one place I never thought to look?

In weakness, when I'm saved by the most unlikely
of heroes. By grace, when I'm invited into

a relationship more loving and intimate than
I could ever imagine as a child of God.

I'll ask you again: what room does fear have
when I step out of the darkness, and I bask

in the light? When I let the past be the past
and the future has no limit. When they can

talk all they want but their opinion doesn't
matter. And when failure is nothing more and

nothing less than the road by which I walk
my path to success.

I'll ask you one last time: what room does
fear have when in His Word, He tells me three

hundred and sixty-five times, depending on
the translation, do not be afraid. As if I

needed to hear that every single day. And
as if that's how many times I needed to hear
it before I finally believed it.

What room does fear have when I make room
for love?
What are you afraid of?

title: What Are You Afraid Of? - Jon Jorgenson

comments.author: Andrew kear

comments.text:
Im afraid of being alone. That my family might someday leave me. That my 
friends would someday go on without me. Nobody likes to be by themselves. 
When im stuck in a room by myself with nothing but my thoughts, I lose my 
confidence. I start thinking of negative things and I start worrying. One 
day, I prayed. I prayed my heart and my soul out crying to him about how 
already lonliness was taking place. Then I felt this feeling of 
reassurance. Like he was with me comforting me. The whole room suddenly 
filled up with sunlight, and since then, I felt more at peace. I love this 
video because it reminds me of that moment and thats all it takes to get me 
through the day! :)﻿

comments.text:
What are you afraid of? Fear sometimes overwhelms us, but what room does 
fear have when we turn everything over to God? We can cling to trust, lean 
on hope, walk by faith, and step into freedom! Like Jon said, depending on 
the translation, the Bible tells us “DO NOT BE AFRAID” approximately 365 
times as if we needed to hear it every day until we start to believe it. 
Stop giving fear room. http://youtu.be/HZIr85Rxln0﻿

comments.author: Patrick Luke

comments.text:
I don't know your precise situation, but let me tell you this (and I am 
trying to be as loving as I can over a keyboard).  Fear and anxieties will 
hinder you from proclaiming Christ to the world.  
“Do not think that I have come to bring peace to the earth. I have not come 
to bring peace, but a sword. For I have come to set a man against his 
father, and a daughter against her mother, and a daughter-in-law against 
her mother-in-law. And a person's enemies will be those of his own 
household. Whoever loves father or mother more than me is not worthy of me, 
and whoever loves son or daughter more than me is not worthy of me." 
--Matthew 10:34-37
Christ calls us to Him and He does everything for His glory.  I was afraid 
at one point of giving up my life.  I mean it was bad.  Addicted to all the 
wrong things, living on my terms, engaging with my family in sexist and 
racist rants (you name it I probably did it outside of illegal drugs.).  I 
didn't want to loose anything I had, but as I am growing in Christ I find 
myself separating even from those I love and don't want to lose. The more I 
learn the more I want to cut the ties completely but I know that it is a 
believing Christians job to share the gospel not just meditate in it and 
you will loose people and things.  It goes to Luke 9:23:
"And he said to all, “If anyone would come after me, let him deny himself 
and take up his cross daily and follow me."

comments.text:
What room does fear have! Fear can cripple the individual from doing what 
the God who is above all (Especially fear) has called the person to do! 
Fear is a crutch we cling to so that we will not doing the boldest and 
radical for the one who did the boldest thing known to man: He died and 
rose again for sinners! Day by Day cling to the reality that it is God who 
is your strength and courage don't fear, but live in the light of God! 
Thank you for this reminder it was one of the 365 reminders that I should 
not fear! :)﻿
